content.raw:
I agree that urdf has its uses. Currently there is a way to go from urdf to
sdf, and it's non-destructive. So, people that need urdf can still use
applications that use sdf, and also have access to the information stored
in urdf.

One of our projects will add coordinate frames to sdf, issue #66, in the
next month or so. This will be the best of both worlds, a graph structure
that also behaves in a similar manner to urdf. This should mostly address
concerns from people who need/use a tree structure.

At that point an sdf to urdf converter would be a very nice way to help
transition people from urdf to sdf.

This is a good discussion, but one that should probably take place off line
or in an issue.

My original concern about this pull request still seems valid. Users of
libsdformat should expect the sdf format. If we merge this in, any existing
user of libsdformat will have to suddenly implement another code path that
handles urdf.
content.html:
I agree that urdf has its uses. Currently there is a way to go from urdf to sdf, and it's non-destructive. So, people that need urdf can still use applications that use sdf, and also have access to the information stored in urdf.

One of our projects will add coordinate frames to sdf, issue #66, in the next month or so. This will be the best of both worlds, a graph structure that also behaves in a similar manner to urdf. This should mostly address concerns from people who need/use a tree structure.

At that point an sdf to urdf converter would be a very nice way to help transition people from urdf to sdf.

This is a good discussion, but one that should probably take place off line or in an issue.

My original concern about this pull request still seems valid. Users of libsdformat should expect the sdf format. If we merge this in, any existing user of libsdformat will have to suddenly implement another code path that handles urdf.
